<notes>Palette extracted from spreadsheet per workflow. Note: proof PDF map appears to use a different color assignment; see validation_and_todos.</notes> </palette_source> <legend> <title>ASIA HIGH AND LOW LEGEND</title> <general_rules> <item>Most metrics use green icons for the “high/favorable” end and orange icons for the “low/unfavorable” end.</item> <item>Exception: “Lowest Crime Rate” is favorable at the low numeric end; green indicates lowest crime and orange indicates highest crime.</item> <item>“Average Household Size” uses a distinct color pair (purple vs blue) to indicate largest vs smallest households (descriptive rather than good/bad).</item> </general_rules> <metrics_in_legend_order> <item>Access To Clean Drinking Water</item> <item>Average Caloric Intake</item> <item>Lowest Crime Rate</item> <item>Access To Healthcare</item> <item>% Population Higher Education Degree</item> <item>Average Household Size</item> <item>Volunteer/Community Service Participation</item> <item>Employment Rates</item> </metrics_in_legend_order> </legend> <map_markers> <capital_marker> <present_on_proof>True</present_on_proof> <description>Small circular markers with a white cross appear across countries (likely capitals).</description> <color_note>Markers appear in orange/red on the proof map.</color_note> </capital_marker> </map_markers> <core_stats_on_map> <item> <stat_id>access_to_clean_drinking_water</stat_id> <label>Access to Clean Drinking Water</label> <maslow_layer>Physiological</maslow_layer> <directionality>higher_is_better</directionality> <high_exemplars> <item> <country>Japan</country> <value_text>~100%</value_text> </item> <item> <country>Singapore</country> <value_text>~100%</value_text> </item> </high_exemplars> <low_exemplars> <item> <country>Cambodia</country> <value_text>~75%</value_text> </item> <item> <country>Afghanistan</country> <value_text>~43%</value_text> </item> </low_exemplars> <source> <file>Asia Cultural Domain.xlsx</file> <sheet>Interesting Statistics</sheet> <range>A4:D12</range> </source> <poster_legend_label>Access To Clean Drinking Water</poster_legend_label> </item> <item> <stat_id>average_daily_caloric_intake</stat_id> <label>Average Daily Caloric Intake</label> <maslow_layer>Physiological</maslow_layer> <directionality>higher_is_better</directionality> <high_exemplars> <item> <country>Turkey</country> <value_text>~3680 cal</value_text> </item> <item> <country>South Korea</country> <value_text>~3340 cal</value_text> </item> </high_exemplars> <low_exemplars> <item> <country>North Korea</country> <value_text>~2100 cal</value_text> </item> <item> <country>Yemen</country> <value_text>~2000 cal</value_text> </item> </low_exemplars> <source> <file>Asia Cultural Domain.xlsx</file> <sheet>Interesting Statistics</sheet> <range>A4:D12</range> </source> <poster_legend_label>Average Caloric Intake</poster_legend_label> </item> <item> <stat_id>crime_rate_low_crime_safety</stat_id> <label>Crime Rate (Low Crime = Safety)</label> <maslow_layer>Safety</maslow_layer> <directionality>lower_is_better</directionality> <high_exemplars> <item> <country>Japan</country> <value_text /> </item> <item> <country>Singapore</country> <value_text /> </item> </high_exemplars> <low_exemplars> <item> <country>Afghanistan</country> <value_text>high due to conflict</value_text> </item> <item> <country>Philippines</country> <value_text>urban crime</value_text> </item> </low_exemplars> <source> <file>Asia Cultural Domain.xlsx</file> <sheet>Interesting Statistics</sheet> <range>A4:D12</range> </source> <poster_legend_label>Lowest Crime Rate</poster_legend_label> </item> <item> <low_exemplars> <item> <country>Afghanistan</country> <value_text><40%</value_text> </item> <item> <country>Yemen</country> <value_text><50% functional healthcare</value_text> </item> </low_exemplars> <source> <file>Asia Cultural Domain.xlsx</file> <sheet>Interesting Statistics</sheet> <range>A4:D12</range> </source> <poster_legend_label>Access To Healthcare</poster_legend_label> </item> <item> persons</value_text> </item> </high_exemplars> <low_exemplars> <item> <country>Japan</country> <value_text>~2.4 persons</value_text> </item> <item> <country>South Korea</country> <value_text>~2.5 <country>Japan</country> <value_text>~28%</value_text> </item> </high_exemplars> <low_exemplars> <item> <country>China</country> <value_text>~12% formally recorded</value_text> </item> <item> Higher Education Degrees</label> <maslow_layer>Esteem</maslow_layer> <directionality>higher_is_better</directionality> <high_exemplars> <item> <country>South Korea</country> <value_text>~70+% of young adults</value_text> </item> <item> <country>Japan</country> <value_text>~60%</value_text> </item> </high_exemplars> <low_exemplars> <item> <country>Nepal</country> <value_text>~7%</value_text> </item> <role>main_map</role> <aspect_ratio>approx 4:3</aspect_ratio> <description>Central Asia map with per-country palette fills and country labels (embedded in proof PDF).</description> <hyperlinks> <final_url /> <url_candidates /> </hyperlinks> </item> </assets> </continent_stats_map> <featurettes> <item> <featurette_id>origination_of_major_religions</featurette_id> <title>Origination of Major Religions</title> <body_text>Long ago, in lands stretching from the Middle East to India, some of the world’s major religions were born. Judaism, Christianity, and Islam arose in the deserts and cities near the Mediterranean Sea. Hinduism and Buddhism took root in India’s rich landscapes, while Sikhism began in the Punjab region.
These faiths shaped how people live, think, and come together. Their ideas spread across the Earth through travel, trade, and teaching, inspiring millions today. By understanding where these religions started and what they share—like respect, kindness, and hope—we can better appreciate the diverse beliefs that guide so many lives.</body_text> <layout_slot_id>featurette_left_top</layout_slot_id> <assets> <item> <asset_id>asia_religions_icons_major_faiths</asset_id> <type>chart</type> <role>symbol_strip</role> <aspect_ratio>approx 6:1</aspect_ratio> <description>Row of icons representing Judaism, Islam, Christianity, Hinduism, Sikhism, and Buddhism (as shown at top of the featurette).</description> <hyperlinks> <final_url /> <url_candidates /> </hyperlinks> </item> <item> <asset_id>asia_religions_illustration_diverse_people</asset_id> <type>chart</type> <role>illustration</role> <aspect_ratio>approx 4:3</aspect_ratio> <description>Illustration of diverse people representing multiple faiths (top-right of the featurette).</description> <hyperlinks> <final_url /> <url_candidates /> </hyperlinks> </item> <item> <asset_id>asia_religions_photo_holy_site</asset_id> <type>photo</type> <role>featurette_photo</role> <aspect_ratio>approx 4:3</aspect_ratio> <description>Photo of a holy site (Western Wall / Jerusalem) used in the Religions featurette.</description> <hyperlinks> <anchor_text>holy site, such as the Wester</anchor_text> <final_url>https://www.touristisrael.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/10/shutterstock_591824696-1024x684.jpg</final_url> <url_candidates /> <notes /> </hyperlinks> </item> <item> <asset_id>asia_religions_map_origins_placeholder</asset_id> <type>map</type> <role>chart_placeholder</role> <aspect_ratio>unknown</aspect_ratio> <description>Referenced in Asia Featurettes.docx: map showing where major religions began. Not clearly present as a standalone map in the proof poster; included as a dependency placeholder.</description> <hyperlinks> <anchor_text>Showing where major religions began</anchor_text> <final_url>https://preview.redd.it/blimtmsmvtm71.jpg?width=1080&crop=smart&auto=webp&s=f26bf7b6b08ea1205df71b8239d9f21185591572</final_url> <url_candidates /> <notes /> </hyperlinks> </item> </assets> <chart_spec> <charts> <item> <chart_id>religion_origin_map</chart_id> <type>map</type> <status>placeholder</status> <title>Where major religions began (map)</title> <data_table> <item> <religion>Christianity</religion> <origin_site_example>Church of the Holy Sepulchre, Jerusalem</origin_site_example> </item> <item> <religion>Judaism</religion> <origin_site_example>Western Wall, Jerusalem</origin_site_example> </item> <item> <religion>Islam</religion> <origin_site_example>Kaaba, Mecca</origin_site_example> </item> <item> <religion>Sikhism</religion> <origin_site_example>Harmandir Sahib (“Golden Temple”), Amritsar</origin_site_example> </item> <item> <religion>Buddhism</religion> <origin_site_example>Mahabodhi Temple, Bodh Gaya</origin_site_example> </item> <item> <religion>Hinduism</religion> <origin_site_example>Kashi Vishwanath Temple, Varanasi</origin_site_example> </item> </data_table> <layout_notes>Featurettes.docx calls for a map + symbols chart. Proof poster shows a symbols strip and a faint world map background, but not a dedicated origin map.</layout_notes> <data_sources> <item> <source_name>Religious Studies Data</source_name> <link /> </item> </data_sources> </item> </charts> <iconography_notes>Symbols shown: Star of David (Judaism), Crescent and star (Islam), Cross (Christianity), Om (Hinduism), Khanda (Sikhism), Dharma wheel (Buddhism).</iconography_notes> <source_table> <file>Asia Cultural Domain.xlsx</file> <sheet>Religions</sheet> <range>A9:F15</range> </source_table> </chart_spec> </item> <item> <featurette_id>india_land_of_contrasts</featurette_id> <title>India – A Land of Contrasts Between Rich and Poor</title> <body_text>India is a land of shining skyscrapers, busy tech hubs, and world-famous business leaders. Yet not far from these modern marvels, you’ll find families who struggle with old tools on small farms or cramped neighborhoods without clean water or electricity.
This big gap between rich and poor comes from a long history and fast changes. Today, India is working hard to share its growing wealth more fairly. New schools, better jobs, and smarter farming methods aim to lift people out of poverty. As India grows, so does the hope that everyone can enjoy a better life.</body_text> <layout_slot_id>featurette_left_bottom</layout_slot_id> <assets> <item> <asset_id>asia_india_photo_luxury_skyscraper</asset_id> <type>photo</type> <role>wealth_symbol_photo</role> <aspect_ratio>approx 3:4 (portrait)</aspect_ratio> <description>Photo of a luxury high-rise/skyscraper (Antilia Tower, Mumbai) used to represent wealth.</description> <hyperlinks> <anchor_text> luxury apartment building ne</anchor_text> <final_url>https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4a/Mumbai_03-2016_19_Antilia_Tower.jpg/1200px-Mumbai_03-2016_19_Antilia_Tower.jpg</final_url> <url_candidates /> <notes /> </hyperlinks> </item> <item> <asset_id>asia_india_photo_crowded_neighborhood</asset_id> <type>photo</type> <role>poverty_contrast_photo</role> <aspect_ratio>approx 16:9</aspect_ratio> <description>Photo of a dense, crowded neighborhood/slum area used to contrast wealth and poverty.</description> <hyperlinks> <anchor_text>small, crowded neighborhood</anchor_text> <final_url>https://c8.alamy.com/comp/2ANTYTK/aerial-view-of-poor-indian-slums-in-faridabad-haryana-2ANTYTK.jpg</final_url> <url_candidates /> <notes /> </hyperlinks> </item> <item> <asset_id>asia_india_photo_rural_farmers</asset_id> <type>photo</type> <role>rural_livelihood_photo</role> <aspect_ratio>approx 16:9</aspect_ratio> <description>Photo of rural farmers working in a field (agriculture / livelihoods).</description> <hyperlinks> <anchor_text>Rural farmers working in a field</anchor_text> <final_url>https://www.bain.com/contentassets/abc6db2a2d8b441f95772b2fa70292e1/india-rural-economy-16-9.jpg</final_url> <url_candidates /> <notes /> </hyperlinks> </item> <item> <asset_id>asia_india_income_regions_map_placeholder</asset_id> <type>map</type> <role>chart_placeholder</role> <aspect_ratio>unknown</aspect_ratio> <description>Referenced in Asia Featurettes.docx: map showing regions with higher incomes and those with lower incomes. Not present in the proof poster PDF; included as a dependency placeholder.</description> <hyperlinks> <final_url /> <url_candidates /> </hyperlinks> </item> </assets> <chart_spec> <charts> <item> <chart_id>india_income_regions_map</chart_id> <type>map</type> <status>placeholder</status> <title>India income regions (higher vs. lower incomes)</title> <data_table /> <layout_notes>Featurettes.docx calls for a government-data income/wealth map, but the proof poster uses a photo-based contrast layout without a visible map.</layout_notes> <data_sources> <item> <source_name>Government Data (India)</source_name> <link /> </item> </data_sources> </item> </charts> </chart_spec> </item> <item> <featurette_id>china_changing_population</featurette_id> <title>China’s Changing Population – A Story of Growth and Change</title> <body_text>Imagine a country growing so fast that leaders once encouraged families to have as many children as possible. That was China after 1949. Soon, the population soared. But too many people meant too few resources, so China introduced the One-Child Policy. Families could only have one child, hoping to slow down the rapid growth.
Over time, this led to more boys than girls, since many parents wanted sons. Today, China faces fewer young people, more elderly, and a changing future. The rules have loosened, allowing more children per family, but raising kids is expensive, and many parents still choose smaller families. China now works to balance its population, care for the elderly, and value all children equally.</body_text> <layout_slot_id>featurette_right_top</layout_slot_id> <assets> <item> <asset_id>asia_china_photo_family_strolling</asset_id> <type>photo</type> <role>featurette_hero_photo</role> <aspect_ratio>approx 16:9</aspect_ratio> <description>Photo of a Chinese family walking in a city street (top of China featurette).</description> <hyperlinks> <anchor_text>A modern Chinese family strolling in a busy city stree</anchor_text> <final_url>https://c8.alamy.com/comp/W9AK8B/file-a-chinese-family-of-three-walk-on-the-nanjing-road-shopping-street-in-shanghai-china-7-july-2010-china-marked-the-30th-anniversary-of-its-W9AK8B.jpg</final_url> <url_candidates /> <notes /> </hyperlinks> </item> <item> <asset_id>asia_china_chart_midyear_population</asset_id> <type>chart</type> <role>supporting_chart</role> <aspect_ratio>approx 4:3</aspect_ratio> <description>Line chart titled “Midyear Population vs. Year” showing China’s midyear population over time.</description> <hyperlinks> <anchor_text>China’s population growth over time</anchor_text> <final_url>https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/u/0/d/1mOnmVei9iEgmQsWWd1iir7fBoPv-WyFv4Wn4V_qOrFs/edit</final_url> <url_candidates /> <notes /> </hyperlinks> </item> <item> <source_table> <file>Asia Cultural Domain.xlsx</file> <sheet>Asia china population featurett</sheet> <range>A5:G81</range> </source_table> <iconography_notes>No iconization math provided (graphs stuff.docx not included).</iconography_notes> </chart_spec> </item> <item> <featurette_id>japan_living_on_the_ring_of_fire</featurette_id> <title>Japan – Living on The Ring of Fire</title> <body_text>Japan sits on the “Ring of Fire,” where giant pieces of Earth’s crust meet and shake. Earthquakes, volcanoes, and tsunamis are part of daily life here.
Instead of fearing these forces, Japan prepares. Buildings sway safely instead of breaking. Alarms on phones give early warnings. Students practice drills so they know what to do when the ground trembles.
In 2011, a huge earthquake and tsunami hit Japan, causing big problems at a nuclear power plant. Since then, safety has improved, and communities stand ready to help each other.
Japan’s story shows that by planning, learning, and working together, people can thrive— even in nature’s most active neighborhood.</body_text> <layout_slot_id>featurette_right_bottom</layout_slot_id> aftermath/result of a tsunami (top of Japan featurette).</description> <hyperlinks> <anchor_text>Showing the result of a tsunami</anchor_text> <asset_id>asia_japan_photo_school_earthquake_drill</asset_id> <type>photo</type> <role>supporting_photo</role> <aspect_ratio>approx 16:9</aspect_ratio> <description>Photo of a school earthquake drill <chart_id>japan_building_resilience_diagram</chart_id> <type>diagram</type> <title>How Japanese buildings resist earthquakes</title> <elements> <item> <label>Seismic Resistance (Taishin)</label> <description>Strengthens columns/walls to withstand shaking.</description> </item> <item> <label>Vibration Control (Seishin)</label> <description>Uses dampers to reduce sway and vibration.</description> </item> <item> <label>Base Isolation (Menshin)</label> <description>Isolates the building from ground motion using bearings/isolators.</description> </item> </elements> <layout_notes>Displayed as a small three-panel illustration at the lower right of the Japan featurette.</layout_notes> <data_sources /> </item> </charts> <iconography_notes>Diagram is conceptual; no
